title: Ticket #82: Review log timestamp format
description:
The current timestamp format is strftime("%m/%d %H:%M:%S "...) in the upcoming 7.3.0. We should review it, and perhaps enhance it.

(In 7.2.x and earlier, it's "%d/%d %02d:%02d:%02d " (month, day, hour, minute, second).)

Possible enhancements:

  • Add the year as the first element. Disk is cheap, and 5 extra bytes per line isn't going to break the bank.
    • Pro:
      • It's occasionally useful when facing very long log files that span 3 or more years. I've run into this in Rust occasionally.
      • It's useful when you run into antique log files.
      • Eliminates confusion if "12/1" is "Jan 12" (European style) or "Dec 1" (US style). 2009/12/01 is pretty unambiguously yyyy/mm/dd. This also helps US readers near the beginning of the year, where they may be expecting 1/12, see 12/1, and accidentally swap them.
      • You can more easily pass the log through sort, even when the log spans a year, and get useful results. This can be useful if you're merging multiple files. (Of course, this necessitates the "pad dates" enhancement listed below.)
    • Con: 99% of the time, it's deadweight.

Done

  • Pad month and date to 2 digits. (02/09 instead of 2/9) Disk is cheap, 0-2 bytes per line is negligable.
  • Implemented in the master (7.3.0) as a side effect of switching to strftime("%m/%d...")
    • Pro: You can more easily pass the log through sort and get useful results. This can be useful if you're merging multiple files.
  • Con: 90% of the time, it's deadweight.
